thread.title: Plane flies over Gillette Stadium with message: ‘Clintons, Patriots, OJ’ - Patriots
thread.title_full: Plane flies over Gillette Stadium with message: ‘Clintons, Patriots, OJ’ - Patriots

author: boston.com
title: Plane flies over Gillette Stadium with message: ‘Clintons, Patriots, OJ’ - Patriots
text:
Another plane?
A banner reading “Clintons, Patriots, OJ” flew over Gillette Stadium Sunday before the Patriots’ matchup against the Jets.
The Patriots are in the company of a group of people suspected of cheating or lying. Former U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton has been embroiled in an email scandal , and her husband, former President Bill Clinton, lied about his affair with Monica Lewinsky. OJ Simpson was tried for murder but found not guilty .
 The Patriots and Tom Brady have been dealing with Deflategate, a ball deflating scandal which started after the AFC Championship Game.
Yeah, this banner flying over Gillette Stadium said "CLINTONS - PATRIOTS - OJ." Don't get it. pic.twitter.com/kz55hCU2gh
— Doug Kyed (@DougKyed) October 25, 2015 . @stoolpresidente @FeitsBarstool just saw this at the pats game. Says "Clinton - Patriots - OJ" pic.twitter.com/KSxRVOBzfw
— Edel? (@Edelson_23) October 25, 2015 It’s unclear who paid for the plane, but Jets fans have previously paid for a similar banner. A group called Jets Fan Media flew a plane over Patriots training camp that said, “ Cheaters look up. ” Jets Fan Media hasn’t tweeted about this plane.
Casting the “Deflategate” movie
Previous -- of -- Next Ben Affleck as Tom Brady: If Ben can don Batman's cape and cowl, the "Good Will Hunting" co-conspiritor has as good a shot as anyone at filling the No. 12 jersey. and Chris Pizzello / AP Previous -- of -- Next Steve Buscemi as Tom Brady Sketch: If Buscemi is the first actor to audition for the role of Brady Sketch 1, then all others would be sent home immediately. Sketch by Jane Rosenberg (left) / Photo courtesy HBO Previous -- of -- Next Elizabeth Banks as Gisele Bundchen: The Pittsfield native's role as Vinnie Papale's love interest in Disney's "Invincible"certainly gives Banks the leg up for the highly coveted role as Tom Brady's supermodel wife. Fernanda Calfat / Getty (left) and Jamie Trueblood / AP Previous -- of -- Next Rob Gronkowski as Rob Gronkowski: There is only one Gronk. Accept no immitations. Robin Marchant / Getty (left) and Charles Krupa / AP Previous -- of -- Next Casey Affleck as Julian Edelman: The younger Affleck makes perfect sense to take on the role as Tom Brady's favorite receiver and superpal Julian Edelman. Scott Eisen / Getty (left) amd David Lee / Universal Pictures Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Conan O'Brien as Roger Goodell: Brookline's own red-headed late-night host would bring a dark, comedic edge to the Commish's character. Richard Drew / AP (left) and Mario Anzuoni / Reuters Previous -- of -- Next Terrence Howard as Ted Wells: Many say the pure acting chops of Howard's "Hustle & Flow" is enough to secure the role of lead Deflategate investigator Ted Wells. But sometimes a good mustache can get you places in this world. Handout photo (left) and Damian Dovarganes / AP Previous -- of -- Next Denis Leary as Bill Belichick: Sarcastic? Check. Unwilling to suffer fools lightly? Check. Experience playing a head coach on the big screen... the Browns even! Check. Slam dunk casting. Jim Davis / The Boston Globe (left) and Todd Heisler / New York Times Previous -- of -- Next Craig Robinson as Vince Wilfork: It's pure swagger that gives Robinson the edge to play the former Patriots nose tackle's role in the film. A hot tub that can travel through time certainly helps. Brynn Anderson / AP (left) and Vivian Zink / NBC Previous -- of -- Next John Slattery as Robert Kraft: Boston's own slick John Slattery of "Mad Men" fame could certainly portray Patriots wealthy owner and unwavering Brady supporter Robert Kraft. Slattery's role as a Ford executive in "Dirty Dancing: Havana Nights" gives him the necessary upper class experience. Gene J. Puskar / AP (left) and Richard Shotwell / AP Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Steve Carell as Walt Anderson: Would you trust Michael Scott from "The Office" to inspect for footballs before the AFC Championship Game? Gene J. Puskar / AP (left) and Disney Enterprises Previous -- of -- Next Jason Mewes as Jim McNalley and Kevin Smith as John Jastremski: Perhaps this could be the perfect - and hilarious - scene from "Deflategate," as the Patriots locker room equipment attendants deliver Brady a basketball after a texting mishap. Photo courtesy of Tracy Bennett Previous -- of -- Next Louis C.K. as the football: The pigskin is the undisputed king of sports these days, and this Boston comedian is undeniably one of the best. Brad Barket / AP Previous -- of -- Next Dane Cook as the pump: Need to take the air out of a fellow comic? Cook could do the trick. Handout Photos Previous -- of -- Next Michael Schur as the Patriots lawyer who wrote The Wells Report in Context: It's not entirely clear if the writer behind Fire Joe Morgan and "Parks & Recreation" - also the actor that played Mose Schrute in "The Office" - was the inspiration for wellreportcontext.com. But judging from the breakdown, is sure seems likely. Wellsreportcontext.com (left) and Photo courtesy of NBC Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Mark Wahlberg and Matt Damon as the Barstool Sports protesters: The quick cameo is perfectly suited for these two Hollywood heavyweights, and also right up the Farrelly brothers alley. Photo courtesy of @LAKEdwards / Twitter (left) and Warner Bros. Previous -- of -- Next James Spader as Jeffrey Kessler: Brady may have only hired high-powered attorney Jeffrey Kessler because Spader's Alan Shore was unavailable... and also fictional. Brendan McDermid / Reuters and Crain Blankenhorn / NBC Previous -- of -- Next Robert De Niro as Richard M. Berman: The iconic actor of "Raging Bull" fits in nicely as New England's favorite U.S. District Court Judge. "Are you looking at me, Roger? Are you looking at me?" Larry Neumeuister / AP (left) and Andrew H. Walker / Getty
